document.docTitle: Trophic discrimination factors and stable isotope variability in a captive feeding trial of the southern rock lobster Jasus edwardsii (Hutton, 1875) (Decapoda: Palinuridae) in Tasmania, Australia

paragraph.docTitle:
Trophic discrimination factors and stable isotope variability in a captive feeding trial of the southern rock lobster
Jasus edwardsii ( Hutton, 1875 )
( Decapoda : Palinuridae ) in Tasmania , Australia

subSection.paragraph:
Jennifer E. Smith 1, , Christian Dietz 2, , John Keane 1, , Craig Mundy 1, , Michael Oellermann
1, 3 ,4,
and Caleb Gardner 1

materialsCitation.docAuthorAffiliation: Institute for Marine and Antarctic Studies, University of Tasmania , Hobart, Tasmania 7005, Australia
Central Science Laboratory , University of Tasmania , Hobart, Tasmania 7005, Australia

paragraph.docAuthorAffiliation:
Centre for Marine Environmental Sciences (MARUM), University of Bremen ,
28359 Bremen , Germany
Alfred Wegener Institute, Helmholtz Centre for Polar and Marine Research, 27570 Bremerhaven, Germany

subSection.paragraph: Correspondence: J.Smith; e-mail: je.smith@utas.edu.au

heading.emphasis: A B ST R A CT

subSection.paragraph:
Trophic discrimination or fractionation factors (TDFs), such as ∆15N and ∆13C, are used in stable isotope mixing models to account for differences between source tissues (diet/prey) and consumer tissues (predator). We aimed firstly to obtain TDF values for a spiny lobster, the southern rock lobster
Jasus edwardsii ( Hutton, 1875 )
, to better understand lobster diet in the wild and secondly to investigate variability in isotope signature within tissues of individuals and across a temporal scale to test if non-lethal sampling can be used in an ecological context. We conducted an 18-mo captive feeding trial with juvenile lobsters using three diet treatments and analysed dorsal and leg muscle, along with dorsal and leg exoskeleton for δ 13 C and δ 15 N values. Average TDFs for the three diet treatments were 3.86 ± 0.98‰ (∆13C) and 5.06 ± 0.65‰ (∆15N) for leg muscle, and 4.45 ± 1.04‰ (∆13C) and 4.36 ± 0.6‰ (∆15N) for dorsal muscle. When tested against wild lobsters and prey, these TDFs outperformed multi-taxa TDFs found in the literature. Isotope values from lobster leg muscle were not identical to associated dorsal muscle but the two were highly correlated, indicating that non-lethal sampling is acceptable. Values for exoskeleton isotope were significantly different from muscle, likely due to the exoskeleton not being in a constant state of growth and replacement, unlike the muscle tissue, which constantly incorporates new material. We conclude that our experimentally derived TDFs are suitable for mixing model analysis for
J. edwardsii
and when tested on a wild sample of lobsters they outperformed other TDFs reported in the literature. We show that non-lethal sampling using leg muscle is an appropriate sampling method, since this tissue is highly correlated to the commonly used dorsal muscle. This option for non-lethal sampling enhances the potential to widely sample wild populations or sample during industrial processing without the need to sacrifice whole animals.

paragraph.heading: KEY WORDS: Crustacea , southern rock lobster , spiny lobsters , stable isotope analysis , trophic discrimination factors ( TDFs )

subSection.paragraph:
The use of stable isotope analysis in food-web ecology and trophic interactions is widespread in ecological studies and is increasingly used for aquaculture and diet investigations on marine organisms. To determine the diet of an animal, various stable isotope mixing models (e.g., MixSIAR, simmr, Fruits) can be used to estimate the proportion of consumer diet from a selection of dietary sources (
Fernandes et al. , 2014
; Parnell & Govan, 2019 ; Stock & Semmens, 2022 ). Due to isotopic fractionation, stable isotope delta values change as organisms sit further up or down the trophic cascade. To assess this change, Trophic Discrimination Factors (TDF, denoted by ∆) are used, which are defined as the difference in isotopic values between food source and consumer. Here, we describe species-specific TDFs which can be used to assess the diet of a spiny lobster, the southern rock lobster
Jasus edwardsii ( Hutton, 1875 )
.

Jasus edwardsii
is a generalist predator on rocky reefs in southeastern Australia and New Zealand (
MacDiarmid et al. , 2013
). The size of maturity of this species varies greatly in Tasmania (
Gardner et al. , 2006
), with the current minimum legal size being 110 mm carapace length (CL) for males and 105 mm / 120 mm CL for females (in southern/northern Tasmania, respectively). Interest in the diet of this predator is currently of high importance due to their perceived potential in providing top-down predatory pressure on a range-extending pest species, the longspined sea urchin
Centrostephanus rodgersii (A. Agassiz, 1864)
(
Ling et al. , 2009
; Ling & Keane, 2021 ). Individuals of
J. edwardsii
are used as a management strategy to control the sea urchin in Tasmania (Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water and Environment, 2018), yet the extent to which the lobster will predate on the sea urchin is uncertain if there are more preferable prey options available (
Smith et al. , 2022
).

The variability of stable isotopes in
J. edwardsii
tissues and muscle TDF values were determined for juvenile lobsters in New Zealand ( Suring & Wing, 2009 ). These TDF values were similar to those provided by Post (2002) , but did not provide adequate coverage for mixing models to provide insight on lobster diet in Tasmania (JS, unpublished data). For this reason, we designed our own 18-mo captive experimental feeding trial with
J. edwardsii
using three different diet treatments to determine 1) species-specific TDFs for use in dietary predicting mixing models, 2) tissue variability within individuals to assess whether non-lethal sampling is suitable for stable isotope work, and 3) timescales on which stable isotopes may vary to verify an optimal sampling method.
Experimental design

An 18-mo controlled captive feeding study was conducted using three groups of juvenile
J. edwardsii
(carapace length 47–101 mm ). The sampling period started in Australian winter ( June 2020 ) and ran through to the second Australian summer ( December 2021 ). Prior to the experiment, lobsters were collected as puerulus from the wild (Iron Pot, Tasmania ) during the summer of 2017–2018 (
Smith et al. , 2023a
, b). These juveniles had been fed a consistent diet of frozen blue mussels
Mytilus galloprovincialis (Lamarck, 1819)
for over two years. Up to 15 lobsters were kept in three separate treatment tanks (approximately 1.5 m diameter × 1.5 m depth, ~2,600 litres) at IMAS Taroona laboratories (Hobart, Tasmania ) with flowing untreated seawater, which is reflective of the natural environment for lobsters in this region. Different sizes and sex of lobsters were randomly assorted between tanks. Lobsters were held communally (in the three treatment tanks). We provided excess food to make sure all lobsters had access to food until the individuals stopped eating; remains were then removed to maintain water quality and avoid nitrate and nitrite accumulation. There were no unexpected mortalities or cannibalisms during the trials. Each tank was supplied with one of the following: frozen whole blue mussels
M. galloprovincialis
(“control/mussel treatment”), frozen whole sea urchin
Centrostephanus rodgersii
(“sea urchin treatment”) or frozen whole sardine
Sardinops sagax (Jenyns, 1842)
(“fish treatment”) 2–3 times per week. Wild sea urchins were collected from the Tasman Peninsula by diving at the beginning of the experiment and stored frozen. Mussels were obtained from a commercial farm at Spring Bay, Tasmania (Spring Bay Seafoods), and sardines from a commercial supplier (Ashmores Southern Fish Markets, Hobart, Tasmania ). Although the same processors were used to source the mussels and fish throughout, we cannot guarantee these were collected at the same time and so could be a source of isotopic variation. These diets were chosen as proxies for lobster diet in the wild (sea urchins, mussels, remains of dead fish;
MacDiarmid et al. , 2013
), and to provide wider trophic differentiation as the three species in the diet options feed at different trophic levels and so are likely to have distinct isotopic signatures. We lethally sampled five lobsters for an initial reference sample: muscle from the hind leg, dorsal cephalothorax muscle, and dorsal exoskeleton. Five lobsters from each experimental setup were non-lethally sampled by removing a hind leg (see
Guest et al. , 2009
). By removing only hind legs, we ensured no lobster was non-lethally sampled more than once. After 12 mo on the controlled, single-species diet, five lobsters and five prey were sampled for stable isotope analysis. Five random lobsters from each treatment were sacrificed and sampled for dorsal, leg, and exoskeleton tissue. Due to the difficulty of identifying individuals through moults, we did not record whether or not a moult matched a previous/subsequent sample from the same individual. Soft tissue from five individual prey animals from each treatment were also sampled. The trial continued until 18 mo when all remaining lobsters were lethally sampled (sea urchin treatment = 8; fish treatment = 4; control/ mussel treatment = 3). Seasonal moulting allowed opportunistic collection of exoskeleton samples from exuviae during two periods between sampling events (4–6 mo and 8–12 mo). Some lobsters from every diet treatment moulted ( N = 13), but not all individuals moulted. Individuals of all treatments moulted during the 4–8 mo period (one lobster moulted in each treatment), individuals of only sea urchin ( N = 6) and fish ( N = 4) treatments moulted during the 8–12 mo period.
Sample preparation

We dissected a 1 cm 3 piece of soft tissue from beneath the leg or dorsal cephalothorax exoskeleton of each lobster, 1 cm 2 exoskeleton samples were also saved from the leg and dorsal cephalothorax carapace. Soft tissue was sampled from five individuals under each diet species: muscle tissue from the fish and mussels and gonads from sea urchins, as these tissues are what we observed to be consumed by the lobsters. All tissue samples from lobsters and diet species were placed into glass vials and oven-dried at 60 °C to a constant weight. Dry samples were then ground into a homogeneous powder using mortar and pestle. About 0.5 mg of sample powder was then weighed and folded into tin capsules for analysis at the Central Science Laboratory, University of Tasmania , Hobart.
Stable isotope analysis
δX (%) = (Rsample/Rstandard – 1) × 1000)

where X = 13 C or 15 N and R = ratio 13 C/ 12 C or 15 N/
14 N.
δ 13 C, and δ 15 N values are reported relative to PDB (Pee Dee Belemnite) and atmospheric air, respectively. We used international reference standards with known isotopic composition (USGS 25, USGS 40, USGS 41, IAEA-N1 and IAEA-N2, NBS 21, USGS 24, and ANU-NAT-76H) to correct for instrumental drift and quality assurance purposes. The analytical performance of the instrumentation, drift correction, and linearity performance were calculated from the repetitive analysis of these standards. Precision was 0.1% for both isotopes. One sample for every source type and the consumer was replicated three time to account for overall precision and homogeneity; error did not exceed 0.33‰ for nitrogen and 0.11‰ for carbon.
Calculating TDFs

We calculated carbon and nitrogen discrimination factors for each diet group by subtracting the mean δ 15 N or δ 13 C value of the diet item from the mean δ 15 N or δ 13 C value of the lobsters in that treatment at 12 mo, following the equation in
Wirtz et al. (2022)
. The distances between the consumer isotope signature and the relative diet-species isotope signature were averaged for the three treatments. Wild lobster isotope signatures were visualised on an isoplot along with average source signatures using no TDFs, TDFs obtained from the literature ( Post, 2002 ; Suring & Wing, 2009 ) and our experimentally derived TDFs.
Wild sample collection

Stable isotope values for wild
J. edwardsii
and potential prey species, collected in January 2021 , were included for verification of our experimentally derived TDFs. Thirty-seven lobster individuals (CL 75–160 mm ), ten of which overlapped in size with our experimental tank lobsters (CL 75–101 mm ), were collected under permit from the Crayfish Point Research Reserve, Hobart, Tasmania and their dorsal cephalothorax tissue sampled for stable isotope analysis. Five soft-tissue samples from source species
Haliotis rubra (Leach, 1814)
(abalone),
Heliocidaris erythrogramma (Valenciennes, 1846)
(sea urchin), and
Lunella undulata (Lightfoot, 1786)
(sea snail) were collected from the same site. All tissue samples were treated as detailed above and underwent the same stable isotope analysis process.
Data analysis

We used split-plot ANOVAs to compare variability of each isotope ( δ 13 C and δ 15 N) between different tissues (dorsal muscle, leg muscle, and exoskeleton) of each lobster. Q-Qplots and Shapiro-Wilk Tests were used to visualise and confirm normality of the data. Linear regression and Pearson’s correlation were performed to determine correlation between isotopes of lobster tissues. Comparisons within tissue types across sampling periods in lobsters from different diet treatments were tested using ANOVA and post-hoc Tukey HSD tests. For lethal samples (initial, 12, and 18 mo), exoskeleton samples are the mean of leg and dorsal samples where both were collected. Exoskeleton for non-lethal samples were only leg samples. Opportunistic moult sample results were analysed separately from those from regular sampling intervals due to unequal and low numbers of replication. All data analysis was conducted using R version 4.1.1 (R Core Team, 2021 ) in RStudio ( RStudio, 2020 ).
Variation between tissues

Split-plot ANOVAs showed that δ 13 C and δ 15 N values were different within individual lobsters between dorsal muscle, leg muscle, and exoskeleton ( δ 13 C F-test (2.09, 50.27) = 189.27, P < 0.001, generalized effect size (ges) = 0.79; δ 15 N F (1.94, 46.5) = 237.61, P < 0.001, ges = 0.71). Pairwise comparisons showed there was no significant difference between dorsal exoskeleton and leg exoskeleton samples ( δ 13 C F (24) = –0.610, P = 1; δ 15 N F (24) = –1.63 P = 1), so these were not included in the linear modelling ( Table 1 ). In all samples tested, lobster leg muscle varied between –18.7 to –16.6‰ in δ 13 C and 12.2 to 15.7‰ in δ
15 N.
Dorsal muscle varied between –18.2 to –16.4‰ in δ 13 C and 11.7 to 14.9 ‰ in δ 15 N, and exoskeleton varied between –18 to –12.2‰ in δ 13 C and 6.7 to 13.5‰ in δ
15 N.

caption.paragraph:
Table 1. Linear models for tissue comparison of
Jasus edwardsii
. The model column describes which tissue are being compared. R-squared (R 2 ) values provide details on how the observed variability in the tissue isotopes were explained by the model. Higher R 2 values show the variability is better explained by the leg muscle-dorsal muscle models than the muscle-exoskeleton models. The t-statistic is shown under t.

tr.th: lm( δ 15N dorsal muscle ∼ δ 15N Leg muscle)
lm( δ 13C dorsal muscle ∼ δ 13C Leg muscle)
lm( δ 13C dorsal muscle ∼ δ 13C Dorsal exoskeleton)
lm( δ 15N dorsal muscle ∼ δ 15N Dorsal exoskeleton)

caption.paragraph:
Figure 1. Correlation plots showing the relationship between samples of captive
Jasus edwardsii
leg muscle and dorsal muscle ( N = 34) for δ 13 C ( A ) and δ 15 N ( B ).

subSection.paragraph: There was a strong linear correlation between muscle tissue samples within individuals for both δ 13 C and δ 15 N ( Fig. 1 ). Equations 2 and 3 show the linear relationship between lobster dorsal and leg muscle tissue for δ 13 C and δ 15 N derived from the linear regression models ( Table 1 ). Pearson’s correlation statistic for leg-dorsal muscle tissue was 0.65 for δ 13 C and 0.87 for δ 15 N; 0.53 for δ 13 C and 0.59 for δ 15 N for dorsal exoskeleton-tissue.
δ 13 C: dorsal δ 13 C = -3.138 + 0.795 × Leg δ 13 C

δ 15 N: dorsal δ 15 N = 3.0433 + 0.7164 × Leg δ 15 N δ 15 N isotope signatures (ANOVA δ 13 C F (31,2) = 0.08, P = 0.92; δ 15 N F (31,2) = 1.65, P = 0.209). Inclusion of size increased the model AIC values for both δ 13 C (AIC 22.7, AIC size 26.5) and δ 15 N (AIC 27.3, AIC size 27.8) and therefore was left out of the final linear model.

Change in isotopic signatures following diet change Overall, mean values of stable isotopes in leg exoskeleton samples were much lower in δ 15 N (9.04 ± 1.8) than the leg muscle samples (13.5 ± 0.9) and higher in δ 13 C (–14 ± 1.4, muscle: –17.8 ± 0.5), and both tissues showed variability over time during the 18-mo time period ( Fig. 2 ).
Leg muscle isotope signature change over time

There was a significant effect of time period and diet treatment on the isotope signature of lobster leg muscle in the experiment (ANOVA δ 13 C F (14, 60) = 10.05, r 2 = 0.701, P < 0.001; ANOVA δ 15 N F (14,60) = 25.02, r 2 = 0.8538, P< 0.001).

footnote.paragraph: (3) When lobster size (mm carapace length) was included in the linear models, it did not significantly influence the relationship between dorsal and leg muscle δ 13 C or dorsal and leg muscle

subSection.paragraph: There was a change in mean isotopic signature for the treatments over time in both δ 13 C and δ 15 N ( Fig. 2 ). After 4 mo, neither of the new diet treatments could be distinguished from the control in δ 13 C (Tukey HSD P

caption.paragraph:
Figure 2. Change in mean (± SE) isotopic signatures over time for captive
Jasus edwardsii
in three diet treatments: sea urchin (●), fish (▲), and mussel (■). Plots show change in δ 13 C ( A ) and change in δ 15 N ( B ). Solid lines represent lobster muscle tissue as represented by a leg-muscle icon, and dashed lines represent lobster exoskeleton as represented by a red-leg exoskeleton icon. Dotted lines represent the mean diet isotope + trophic discrimination factor (TDF) calculated as of 12 months. All mean values have a minimum sample size of five replicates except for

the following samples: 4-month mussel ( N = 4), 18-month fish ( N = 4), and 18-month mussel ( N = 3). For lethal samples (initial, 12, and 18 monts), exoskeleton samples are the mean of leg and dorsal samples where both were collected. Exoskeleton samples are only leg samples for non-lethal samples.

subSection.paragraph: (mussel-urchin)
(mussel-fish)

= 0.06) or δ 15 N (Tukey HSD P (mussel-urchin) = 0.26, P (mussel-fish) = 0.99), but lobsters from the sea urchin treatment were significantly higher in δ 13 C value than those in the fish treatment (Tukey HSD P < 0.001). By 8 mo, lobsters in the sea urchin treatment had isotopic signatures significantly different in δ 13 C value from those in the control treatment (Tukey HSD P < 0.001) and the fish treatment (Tukey HSD P = 0.002); this diet group remained distinct in δ 13 C for the rest of the experiment (Tukey HSD P (12 month-mussel) < 0.001, P (12 month-fish) = 0.004, P (18 month-mussel) < 0.001, P (18 month-fish) = 0.001). δ 15 N values for all treatments remained within the range of the control treatment at 4 mo (ANOVA F (2,12) =1.72, P = 0.221) but by 8 mo the lobsters on the sea urchin diet were higher in δ 15 N compared to those in the control (Tukey HSD P = 0.004). By 12 mo, the two new diet treatments were both enriched in δ 15 N compared to those in the control (Tukey HSD P (mussel-urchin) = 0.001, P (mussel-fish) = 0.002). There was a steep rise in the δ 15 N across lobsters in all treatments at 18 mo ( Fig. 2 ).
Exoskeleton isotope signature change over time

There was a significant effect of sample period but not treatment on δ 13 C isotope value of lobster exoskeleton samples across the whole sampling period (ANOVA F (14,59) = 2.5, P = 0.007). Prior to the 12-mo sampling, treatment had no effect on δ 13 C (ANOVA F 4month (2,11) = 0.05, P = 0.951, F 8month(2,12) = 0.66, P = 0.534). At 12 mo, lobsters in the sea urchin treatment had significantly higher exoskeleton δ 13 C values than those in the fish treatment (Tukey HSD P = 0.016) and this pattern continued at 18 mo (Tukey HSD P = 0.023). There was a significant effect of sample period and treatment and an interaction across the whole experiment (ANOVA F (14, 59) = 23.55, P < 0.001) for δ 15 N values in lobster exoskeleton. There was no difference between treatments (ANOVA F (2,11) = 0.278, P = 0.763) at 4 mo, but by 8 mo the lobsters in the fish treatment had become significantly enriched in δ 15 N compared to the control (Tukey HSD P = 0.005), lobsters in the sea urchin and mussel treatments remained similar (Tukey HSD P = 0.08). Throughout the first 12 mo, lobsters in the new diet treatments maintained similar δ 15 N exoskeleton values, and these were both significantly higher than the control at the 12-mo sampling (Tukey HSD P (mussel-urchin) < 0.001, P (mussel-fish) < 0.001). Like δ 15 N in the leg muscle samples, there was a steep increase in δ 15 N of exoskeleton of lobster in all treatments between 12 and 18 mo ( Fig. 2 ).

Opportunistically, we sampled 13 moulted exuviae for exoskeleton analysis between the established sampling periods: one from each treatment during the period of 4-8 mo ( N = 3) and six from the sea urchin treatment (mean ± SE, δ 13 C –12.4 ± 0.2, δ 15 N 8.4 ± 0.2) and four from the fish treatment ( δ 13 C –12 ± 0.4, δ 15 N: 8.4 ± 0.3) during 8–12 mo ( N = 10).

Calculating a Trophic Discrimination Factor Captive lobsters in different treatments had different mean isotope values from the control treatment (mussel-fed lobsters) after 12 mo. We calculated TDF values sing the mean isotope value at 12 mo from the lobsters and the isotope values from the sources ( Table 2 ). Mean ± SD isotope values for the sources were as follows: mussel δ 13 C –20.34 ± 0.77, δ 15 N 8.02 ± 0.39 ( N = 4); sea urchin δ 13 C –21.53 ± 1.74, δ 15 N 7.66 ± 0.28 ( N = 5); fish δ 13 C –22.28 ± 0.45, δ 15 N 9.03 ± 0.37 ( N = 5).
Testing the obtained trophic discrimination factors

Figure 3 illustrates the comparison of using different TDF values on a population of wild lobsters and diet sources. Sources with the correction for experimentally derived TDFs for both leg muscle and dorsal muscle overlap the consumer population and would therefore be acceptable to use in stable isotope mixing models. Sources corrected for TDFs found in the literature (∆13C 0.4‰ and ∆15N; 3.4‰ and ∆13C 0.84‰ and ∆15 N 3.28 ‰ ( Post, 2002 ; Suring & Wing, 2009 )), improve the fit of the sources from no TDFs at all but do not correct the sources to overlap the consumer population and so would have to be considered inappropriate for use in mixing models.

By using a controlled experimental feeding trial, we were able to assess tissue variability, changing isotopic signatures over time, and determine species- and tissue-specific trophic discrimination factors for juvenile
J. edwardsii
in Tasmania .

The variation in isotope signatures of invertebrates was not assessed by
Caut et al. (2009)
, but their study did find tissue type was a significant factor affecting isotope signature in some vertebrates (fishes and birds). We found a large difference in isotope signatures between lobster muscle tissue and exoskeleton and a smaller difference between dorsal and leg muscles. The range of isotope values we collected fall around the mean found in wild
J. edwardsii (
Guest et al. , 2009
)
and within the range seen in another species of rock lobster (e.g.,
Sagmariasus verreauxi (H. Milne Edwards, 1851 ) (
Day et al. , 2022
)
.

The tissue variability we found between the samples of leg and dorsal muscle in
J. edwardsii
is significant but highly correlated, meaning the use of non-lethal leg samples would be warranted with the correction factor provided for δ 13 C and δ 15 N (equations 2, 3). A similar conclusion was made in the study of another species of rock lobster (
S. verreauxi
), in which the authors provide a correction formula to use leg tissue isotopic signature to provide information for the lobster (
Day et al. , 2022
). We do not recommend using exoskeleton tissue in the same way due to the low correlation and R 2 values. Further, temporal sampling of exoskeleton indicates that δ 13 C does not change with diet change in the same way that the muscle tissue does ( Fig. 2 ), likely representing the diet at the time of laying the exoskeleton rather than the recently assimilated diet.

Over the timeline of the 18-mo experiment, we can observe that within 4 mo, change of diet can have a significant impact on the consumer’s isotopic signature ( Fig. 2 ). For this reason, the time frame in which samples were collected from the wild must be taken into account in all isotope studies. For example, if season changes prey availability and thus diet, consumer isotope signature could shift seasonally and so if comparability is important to the study, we recommend that samples should be collected within a short time frame (e.g., less than 4 mo apart). The moulted exuviae were enriched in mean δ 13 C when compared to non-lethal exoskeleton samples either side of the moult. This could be related to the reabsorption processes which occurs in spiny lobsters prior to moult ( Zoutendyk, 1988 ); however, we had insufficient samples to pursue this theory further.

caption.paragraph:
Table 2. Mean isotope values for tissues of
Jasus edwardsii
in each treatment at the 12-month sampling. Data shown are for leg and dorsal tissues. TDFs (Δ) were calculated for both tissue types in each treatment by subtracting the average δ 13 C or δ 15 N value of the diet item from the average δ 13 C or δ 15 N value of the tissue in the associated treatment. N = 5 for all groups.

Figure 3. Isoplot showing the fit of different trophic discrimination factors (TDFs) to a wild population of
Jasus edwardsii
(■) and associated wild prey sources:
Haliotis rubra
(▲),
Heliocidaris erythrogramma
(■), and
Lunella undulata
(●), demonstrating that our experimentally derived TDFs provide the best fit. Black dots represent the isotope signatures of individual dorsal-muscle samples of lobsters. Mean and standard deviation values refer to the three source signatures with no TDF correction, with correction using multi-taxa TDFs from the literature (∆13C 0.4‰ and ∆15N 3.4‰ ( Post, 2002 )) and previously determined TDFs for
J. edwardsii
(∆13C 0.84‰ and ∆15N 3.28‰ ( Suring & Wing, 2009 )), with correction using our experimentally determined dorsal muscle TDFs (∆13C 4.45‰ and ∆15N 4.36‰), and correction with our experimentally determined leg muscle TDFs (∆13C 3.86‰ and ∆15N 5.05‰).

subSection.paragraph:
Our experimentally derived TDF values of ∆13C (4.45 ± 1.04) and ∆15N (4.36 ± 0.6) for dorsal muscle and ∆13C (3.86 ± 0.98) and ∆15N (5.06 ± 0.65) for leg muscle are higher than the mean TDFs reported by
Caut et al. (2009)
but do fall in the range of TDFs they found within their analysis. These values are also higher than those found by Suring & Wing (2009) in juvenile
J. edwardsii
from New Zealand . The TDFs we supply here are intended for use with
J. edwardsii
in Tasmania but it would be advantageous to test the validity of the TDFs with the same species in other locations and similar species elsewhere as it appears that the geographic location can influence TDFs within the same species. We provide evidence that TDFs are highly efficient at improving the fit of the wild consumer and prey data ( Fig. 3 ).

We used juvenile
J. edwardsii
because particular individuals had been in captivity for two years prior so we could be certain of their feeding history and being juvenile they were more likely to moult and experience a change of exoskeleton during the experiment. We nevertheless ensured the size range of those in our experiments did overlap with ones caught in the wild for testing of the TDF values to demonstrate that the experimental individuals we sampled were comparable. It must be considered that discrimination factors can be influenced by lobster growth in captivity (
Wirtz et al. , 2022
) and rapid growth during this life stage could increase the variability of isotope signatures ( Suring & Wing, 2009 ). Despite this, when tested for a range of different-size wild lobsters, our TDFs did outperform others from the literature for
J. edwardsii
in Tasmania . It was important to the outcomes of this study to test the validity of our TDFs for larger sized lobsters in the field, as these are likely to be targeted for diet analysis due to their potential to predate on the range-extending sea urchin (
Ling et al. , 2009
).

This study has provided a less invasive, non-lethal sampling protocol for
J. edwardsii
in the wild and TDFs to assess lobster diet in relation to its role as a top-down predator of range-extending pest sea urchins in Tasmania . We have provided evidence that non-lethal sampling of leg muscle in
J. edwardsii
can be used in place of lethally collected dorsal muscle for stable isotope analysis. We showed that experimentally derived, species- and tissue-specific TDFs outperform literature based TDFs for use in diet studies and mixing models for
J. edwardsii
in the wild or in the laboratory. We recommend time-relevant sampling of stable isotope tissue samples due to the potential for variability in isotope signatures over a temporal scale.
Supplementary material is available at Journal of Crustacean Biology online.
S1 Figure. Monthly average of water salinity and temperature during experimental trials. All underlying data for this study

were published as open access at the PANGAEA data repository (
Smith et al. , 2023a
, b)

paragraph.heading: ACK N O W LE D G E M E N TS

subSection.paragraph: We acknowledge the palawa , traditional custodians of lutruwita ( Tasmania ), in which this study took place. JS would like to thank Shenae Willis for laboratory assistance. Funding for stable-isotope analysis was provided by the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation (FRDC project 2021-020 “Stable isotopes: a rapid method to determine lobster diet and trace lobster origin?”) MO was supported by the German Research Foundation (DFG) fellowship 326692763 [https://gepris. dfg.de/gepris/projekt/326692763?language=en]. The authors would like to thank the Derwent Estuary Program for providing water quality data. The authors would also like to thank the anonymous reviewers. The contribution by the authors was as follows: conception: JS, JK; Data collection/analysis: JS; writing: JS, CD; review: JS, CD, JK, MO, CM, CG.
